channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2017 The New York Times Company

item.title: Tehran’s Turn: The New patriots: Long Divided, Iran Unites Against Trump and Saudis in a Nationalist Fervor
item.media:description: A billboard in a central Tehran square showing Mohsen Hojaji, an obscure 26-year-old who was killed fighting in Syria and is now being promoted as a national hero.
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.description: Once sneering and cynical about the government, middle-class, reform-minded Iranians are now backing their hard-line leaders amid a surge in patriotism.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Pope Francis Arrives in a Myanmar Tarnished by Rohingya Crackdown
item.media:description: Pope Francis after his arrival on Monday at the airport in Yangon, Myanmar.
item.description: The pope met with the top commander of the military, which has led a campaign to drive Rohingya Muslims out. He will meet Daw Aung San Suu Kyi on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: Prince Harry Is Engaged to Meghan Markle
item.media:description: Prince Harry and Meghan Markle at Kensington Palace on Monday after their engagement was announced.
item.description: The prince, a grandson of Queen Elizabeth II, and Ms. Markle, an American actress, will be married in the spring, the royal family said.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO de FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: Tokyo Journal: Tokyo, Once a Cigarette Haven, Could Finally Kick Out the Smokers
item.media:description: Tokyo is considering a ban on smoking indoors in most public places. In this intensely rule-abiding country, some say changing smoking rules would test the resolve of many.
item.media:credit: Tomohiro Ohsumi for The New York Times
item.description: A no-smoking ordinance being considered by the city raises the question of whether the famously rule-abiding Japanese would obey it.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: Pakistan Strikes Deal With Islamist Protesters in Islamabad
item.media:description: Smoke rising from a clash between security forces and protesters in Islamabad, Pakistan, on Saturday. On Monday, Pakistan’s government said the law minister would step down in return for an end to the demonstrations.
item.description: In an agreement brokered by the army, the law minister, whom protesters accused of blasphemy, resigned in return for peace on the capital’s streets.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Bali Volcano Eruption Triggers More Evacuations
item.media:description: The Mount Agung volcano spewing hot ash on Monday. The probability of a bigger eruption is increasing, Indonesia’s volcanology center said.
item.description: Officials have expanded an exclusion zone over fears that a larger eruption could follow.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: In Honduras Election, Ex-Sportscaster Takes Lead Over President
item.media:description: Supporters of Salvador Nasralla rejoiced early Monday as vote tallies were released in Tegucigalpa, Honduras.
item.description: A victory by Salvador Nasralla, an ex-sportscaster, would be a rebuke to President Juan Orlando Hernández and his authoritarian administration.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: The Talk of Turkey? A Politically Charged Trial in New York
item.media:description: Reza Zarrab, a Turkish-Iranian businessman accused of conspiracy to violate United States sanctions against Iran, is scheduled to go on trial in New York on Monday.
item.description: Turkish officials are watching closely as the U.S. prepares to try two prominent Turks accused of helping their country violate the embargo against Iran.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL and BENJAMIN WEISER

item.title: Sabbath Railway Work in Israel Shakes Netanyahu’s Coalition
item.media:description: Yaakov Litzman, Israel’s health minister, after handing in his resignation on Sunday in protest over railway maintenance work done on the Sabbath.
item.description: A resurgence of Israel’s so-called Sabbath wars leads an ultra-Orthodox minister to quit on his rabbi’s orders, putting pressure on others in Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s cabinet.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: How Prince Harry Proposed to Meghan Markle
item.description: Prince Harry and his fiancée, Meghan Markle, an American actress and humanitarian, describe how they became engaged. Yes, he got down on one knee.

item.title: Glyphosate, Top-Selling Weed Killer, Wins E.U. Approval for 5 Years
item.media:description: Edward Ford on his farm in Brentwood, England, where he relies on the weed killer glyphosate.
item.description: The decision to reauthorize use of the world’s best-selling herbicide for an abbreviated period was made amid opposition from several of the union’s member states, including France and Italy.
item.dc:creator: DANNY HAKIM

item.title: The Breakdown: How to Fix Australia’s Paralyzed Parliament
item.media:description: Skye Kakoschke-Moore, an Australian-British citizen, announced her resignation from the Senate on Wednesday as the leader of her party, Nick Xenophon, looked on.
item.description: Nine lawmakers were forced to resign because they are dual citizens. Scholars have a few ideas about how to change that.
item.dc:creator: ISABELLA KWAI

item.title: After Tumultuous Week, Germany’s Politics Look to the Familiar
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel with leaders of her Christian Democratic Union party during a meeting in Berlin on Monday.
item.description: Leaders of the German chancellor’s conservative party say a coalition with the Social Democrats would provide more stability than a minority government.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Vietnamese Blogger Gets 7 Years in Jail for Reporting on Toxic Spill
item.media:description: Nguyen Van Hoa at his trial in Ha Tinh, Vietnam, on Monday. He was convicted of spreading anti-state propaganda for producing videos and writing about protests over an environmental disaster.
item.media:credit: Cong Tuong/Vietnam News Agency, via Associated Press
item.description: Nguyen Van Hoa was convicted of spreading information about the discharge that killed marine life and sickened people along a 120-mile stretch of coastline.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: Fontana, an Artist Ahead of His Time
item.description: Lucio Fontana, who died in 1968, was best known for his slashes on canvas. An exhibition in Milan is casting a new light on a less known part of his work that sets him at the forefront of art installation.

item.title: Shohei Ohtani, Japan’s Two-Way Star, Aims to Take M.L.B. Back to Its Future
item.media:description: Shohei Ohtani hitting a home run during an international exhibition game between Japan and the Netherlands at the Tokyo Dome last year.
item.description: Ohtani, 23, is a coveted left-handed slugger and right-handed pitcher who wants to come to the major leagues as the first player in decades to regularly play a dual role.
item.dc:creator: JAMES WAGNER

item.title: Twitter Says Blocking a New York Times Account Was ‘an Error’
item.description: The Times’s international account was locked after a tweet on the Canadian prime minister. The account was down for nearly a day.
item.dc:creator: NELLIE BOWLES

item.title: As Aid Arrives in Yemen, U.N. Warns It Must Not Be a ‘One-Off’
item.media:description: A ship carrying food aid docked at the Yemeni port city of Al Hudaydah on Sunday.
item.description: Weeks after a Saudi-led coalition blockaded airports and seaports in Yemen, aid shipments of food and medical supplies have begun re-entering ports.
item.dc:creator: MEGAN SPECIA

item.title: Amazon, in Hunt for Lower Prices, Recruits Indian Merchants
item.media:description: Workers at a factory in Jaipur, India, making bedsheets for The Boho Street, an Indian company that sells its products on Amazon.
item.media:credit: Rebecca Conway for The New York Times
item.description: Thousands of Indian sellers have shipped bedding, jewelry, kitchenware and clothing to Amazon warehouses to serve bargain-hunting Americans.
item.dc:creator: VINDU GOEL

item.title: Two Former Mugabe Allies Are Held Without Bail in Zimbabwe
item.media:description: Ignatius Chombo, center left, and Kudzanai Chipanga — former allies of Zimbabwe’s ousted president — being led to a prison truck at the magistrates court in Harare, Zimbabwe, on Saturday.
item.description: Their cases are being closely watched for signs about how the new government will deal with former allies of the ousted president.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY MOYO

item.title: Myanmar General’s Purge of Rohingya Lifts His Popular Support
item.media:description: Senior General Min Aung Hlaing, Myanmar’s military chief, possesses enormous political and economic power.
item.media:credit: Ye Aung Thu/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Senior Gen. Min Aung Hlaing’s campaign to drive out Muslims, which is widely approved of by Myanmar’s Buddhist majority, may help lead him to the presidency.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Kabul Journal: In Her Film About Afghan Life, the Woman Slaps Back
item.media:description: Roya Sadat with her son at her film company’s offices in Kabul, Afghanistan. Ms. Sadat’s latest film, “A Letter to the President,” is Afghanistan’s submission for best foreign language film at the Oscars.
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.description: Roya Sadat sold her apartment, car and jewelry to make a movie that deepens the conversation on women’s rights. It’s Afghanistan’s selection for the Oscars now.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Pope Francis’ Dilemma in Myanmar: Whether to Say ‘Rohingya’
item.media:description: Catholics arriving in Yangon, Myanmar, on Saturday, ahead of a visit by Pope Francis.
item.media:credit: Ye Aung Thu/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The pope, who is visiting on Monday, received a plea from the nation’s cardinal not to mention the Muslim minority but focus on the group in “a way that doesn’t hurt anybody.”
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Pakistan Deploys Military Troops After Violent Clashes in Islamabad
item.media:description: Police officers on Sunday in Islamabad, Pakistan, with motorcycles burned by Islamist protesters.
item.description: Military and government officials met in the capital in a bid to restore law and order after deadly clashes between supporters of a firebrand cleric and the police.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: No Man’s Land: Barbuda After Irma
item.description: The Caribbean island of Barbuda felt the full force of Hurricane Irma. Now, a struggle to control its future is underway. On one side are Barbudans who own the land and want to preserve their unique way of life — on the other, the government and foreign investors who see opportunity in disaster.

item.title: As Anti-Semitism Rises, ‘I Don’t Feel Safe in Australia,’ Rabbi Says
item.media:description: Far-right groups held an “Australian pride march” in Melbourne in June. Jewish groups in Australia are concerned by the rise of far-right activists who are singling out Jews.
item.description: Acts of anti-Semitism have increased nearly 10 percent over the past year in Australia, a report by a Jewish council says.
item.dc:creator: AARTI BETIGERI

item.title: If No One Owns the Moon, Can Anyone Make Money Up There?
item.media:description: The moon has been overlooked since NASA's Apollo missions. Private companies are now looking to set up shop.
item.description: Ambiguities in the 50-year-old Outer Space Treaty may be getting in the way of entrepreneurs seeking opportunities elsewhere in our solar system.
item.dc:creator: KENNETH CHANG

item.title: In Peru’s Deserts, Melting Glaciers Are a Godsend (Until They’re Gone)
item.media:description: A glacier in the Cordillera Blanca region of Peru. Its melting has been a bonanza for farmers, but the water may soon be gone.
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.description: Accelerating glacial melt in the Andes caused by climate change has set off a gold rush downstream, letting the desert bloom. But as the ice vanishes, the vast farms below may do the same.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: Mount Agung in Bali Erupts Again, Spurring Evacuation of Thousands
item.media:description: Mount Agung spewed ash and steam more than 19,000 feet into the skies this weekend.
item.description: The eruption, the second in a week on the Indonesian island, also left thousands of airline passengers stranded.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: A Defiant Map-Hunter Stakes Vietnam’s Claims in the South China Sea
item.media:description: Tran Duc Anh Son, a historian in Danang, Vietnam, says his government is afraid to use the records he uncovered to challenge Beijing. “That’s why we have many documents that are kept in the dark.”
item.media:credit: Quinn Ryan Mattingly for The New York Times
item.description: He scoured the world for evidence to make his case, but a scholar now finds his government reluctant to challenge Beijing, its powerful rival.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES

item.title: ‘Sick With Sexism,’ France Must Fight Violence Against Women, Macron Says
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron speaking on Saturday in Paris. “We must all feel responsible,” he said, referring to violence against women.
item.description: Emmanuel Macron pledged to make combating violence against women a top priority of his government, but critics argued he has not committed enough resources to the cause.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: Lebanon’s Vanishing Prime Minister Is Back at Work. Now What?
item.media:description: Prime Minister Saad Hariri, center, greeting the audience on Thursday at a regional banking conference in Beirut. He has returned with his position strengthened, a member of a rival party said.
item.description: Saad Hariri, absent for three weeks and seemingly forced to resign by Saudi Arabia, is faced with an intractable clash of Saudi and Iranian interests.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and HWAIDA SAAD

item.title: ‘Comfort Women’ Statue in San Francisco Leads a Japanese City to Cut Ties
item.media:description: A memorial for “comfort women” in St. Mary’s Square in San Francisco. The mayor of Osaka wants to terminate the relationship between his city and San Francisco because of the statue.
item.description: A long-running dispute between South Korea and Japan was reignited by a memorial for women who were sex slaves during World War II.
item.dc:creator: JACEY FORTIN

item.title: Three Sailors Lost in Plane Crash Near Japan Are Identified
item.media:description: From left: Bryan Grosso, an aviation ordnanceman airman apprentice; Lt. Steven Combs; and Matthew Chialastri, an aviation boatswain’s mate airman.
item.description: The United States Navy identified the men as Bryan Grosso, Steven Combs and Matthew Chialastri.
item.dc:creator: VIVIAN WANG
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: In Egypt, Furious Retaliation but Failing Strategy in Sinai
item.media:description: Damaged vehicles outside a Sufi mosque attacked by Islamist militants in Bir al-Abed, Egypt. A government official said the gunmen had set fire to cars parked outside the mosque to hinder escape.
item.description: One of the most striking aspects of the carnage at a Sinai mosque: How easy it was for militants to carry it out.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH and DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: : Banking on Tito’s Yacht to Steer a Cultural Renaissance
item.media:description: Galeb, the nearly 80-year-old yacht that once belonged to the Yugoslav leader Josip Broz Tito, has been rusting for years in Rijeka, Croatia.
item.description: Rijeka, Croatia, anointed a European capital of culture, wants to restore and showcase the rusting boat used by the Yugoslav leader, but far-right nationalists are outraged.
item.dc:creator: BARBARA SURK

item.title: To the World, They Are Muslims. To ISIS, Sufis Are Heretics.
item.media:description: Visitors at the Alif Khan Mosque during the Sufi Festival last year in Dholka, India.
item.description: Hundreds of people have been killed inside Sufi mosques in the past year by militants. To ISIS, not one of them was considered a Muslim.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Teacher Detained After Abuse Allegations at Beijing Kindergarten
item.media:description: People gathered outside the gates of RYB Kindergarten in the Xintiandi area of Beijing on Friday.
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Parents have said their children were drugged and forced to strip. The accusations have triggered outrage across China.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Fire at Black Sea Resort Hotel in Georgia Kills 11
item.media:description: Ambulances and police officers at the scene after at least 11 people died in a fire at the Leogrand Hotel in the Black Sea resort city of Batumi, Georgia, on Saturday.
item.description: The 22-story Leogrand Hotel in Batumi was previously been fined for failing to comply with safety regulations, a local official said.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: Distaste for Honduran Leaders Who Linger Fuels Distrust in Election
item.media:description: A campaign rally for the conservative party of President Juan Orlando Hernández in Tegucigalpa, Honduras.
item.media:credit: Daniele Volpe for The New York Times
item.description: The re-election bid of President Juan Orlando Hernández has turned into a referendum on how much control over the country’s fragile institutions Honduran voters are willing to cede.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: Pakistan Calls In Army to Help Restore Order After Violent Clashes in Islamabad
item.media:description: Protesters hurled back a tear-gas canister fired by the police during clashes near Islamabad, Pakistan, on Saturday.
item.description: Thousands of officers moved against a sit-in led by a firebrand cleric that has paralyzed the capital, with at least six deaths and 150 arrests.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: India’s Gay Rights Activists Seize Momentum After Landmark Ruling
item.media:description: The drag queen Alaska, a recent winner of “RuPaul’s Drag Race: All Stars,” performing at an event held after the pride march in New Delhi this month.
item.media:credit: Rebecca Conway for The New York Times
item.description: A Supreme Court decision that citizens have a constitutional right to privacy is seen as a crucial advance in the fight against a law criminalizing sex between men.
item.dc:creator: KAI SCHULTZ
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships

item.title: China Limits Waste. ‘Cardboard Grannies’ and Texas Recyclers Scramble.
item.media:description: A woman breaking down a cardboard box for recycling in Hong Kong last month. Thousands of small-time scrap collectors in Hong Kong sell waste to traders to be processed and exported to mainland China or elsewhere.
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.description: An intense crackdown by Chinese regulators on imported foreign waste destined to be recycled has had an impact on businesses and municipalities around the world.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES

item.title: Violence Flares as Nepal Heads to Landmark Elections
item.media:description: Nabindra Raj Joshi, center, a candidate in Sunday’s elections, campaigned in Kathmandu this past week. The elections have been called the largest democratic exercise ever in Nepal.
item.description: As the Himalayan country prepares to hold its most important vote in years on Sunday, Maoists who want it stopped have carried out a series of attacks.
item.dc:creator: RAJNEESH BHANDARI and KAI SCHULTZ

item.title: The Land of Apology and a Return to Montreal: The Canada Letter
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau in the House of Commons, where he will present an apology for a program that drove gays and lesbians out of the government and military.
item.description: This week’s newsletter about Canada and for Canadians looks into Canadians’ tendency to say sorry and welcomes an expat home.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Egypt, Michael Flynn, Argentina: Your Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: PENN BULLOCK and SANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: Who Are Sufi Muslims and Why Do Some Extremists Hate Them?
item.media:description: Muslims praying at the shrine of a Sufi saint on Wednesday in Srinagar, Kashmir.
item.description: A terrorist attack in Egypt has focused attention on the mystical school of Islam, which emphasizes the inward search for divinity.
item.dc:creator: MEGAN SPECIA
